No particular character identifies a varible in JavaScript as the dollar sign does in PHP. 

Variables use the following naming rules:
  • A varible may include only the letters a-z, A-Z, 0-9, $ and the underscrore _
  • No other characters, such as space or punctuation
  • Names are case sensitive
  • No set limit on varible name lengths

Variables

Should be enclose in a single or double quotation marks
You may include a sinlge quote within double-quoted string or a double quote within a single quoted string, but you must escape using the backslash character

greeting = "\"Hello there\" is a greeting"
warning = '\'Be Careful\' is a warning'
JavaScript is loosely typed, the type of a varible is only deteremined when a value is assigned and it can change as the varible appears in different contexts.

n = '838102050' // Set 'n' to a string
console.log('n='+ n + ',and is a ' + typeof n + '</br>')

n = 1234 * 6789; // Set 'n' to a number
console.log('n='+ n + ',and is a ' + typeof n + '</br>')
